text: Postage stamp size. Clothes on the line. The sunlight cut by the cramped crowd of houses. We're already PULLING AWAY FROM the backs of two men. Drinking beer, smoking Luckys and sharing a laugh. An 11-year-old boy leans on a street hockey stick, watches them. JIMMY MARCUS, unspent energy coiled tight in his chest. His friend SEAN DEVINE steps over, holds up an orange street hockey ball.
Got it. Jimmy's attention is fixed on his and Sean's fathers.
Hey, Jimmy. Sean punches him in the arm. As Jimmy looks hard over, Sean wiggles the ball, raises his eyebrows.

Wearing a Red Sox cap, DAVE BOYLE stands eagerly before a makeshift chicken wire goalie net as Jimmy and Sean whack away at the orange ball with their street hockey sticks. As it bounces toward Dave, he takes an arcing swing at it. Connects. The ball sails.
Save! Sean and Jimmy watch as the ball bounces into the street.
The sewer... They charge off after it.
The ball rolls, disappears down a storm drain. BOOM UP to see the boys arriving too late to stop it. Jimmy and Sean look back at Dave bringing up the rear. Looking guilty.
Sorry, guys. (smiling) Guess I don't know my own strength.
Yeah, Dave, that must be it. As Sean gets down on his hands and knees to look down into the sewer, Jimmy looks up and down the street.
You know what would be cool?
What?
Driving a car. Sean looks up from the storm drain.
You know. Just around the block.
Yeah...
Anyone on this street keep their keys in their car? Sean and Dave exchange a look. Jimmy's crazy.
( (standing) I steal a car, my dad'll kill me.

Just around the block. Who said steal?  Sean shakes his head "no." Jimmy heaves a sigh. Jimmy walks to where sawhorses have been set up. City crews have replaced several squares of sidewalk. Yellow caution tape is tied to the sawhorses creating a barricade. Jimmy snaps the tape by walking right through it. Jimmy grabs a stick and starts to write his name. Sean and Dave step up, look over his shoulder, J-I-M-M-Y. Jimmy looks back over his shoulder.
Your dad kill you for writing your name, too? Sean takes the stick, squats down. S-E-A-N. Jimmy smiles.
Now it'll be there forever.

Me, too. Forever. Dave takes the stick, starts his own name by the other two. D-A -- A little SQUEAL as a CAR lurches to a stop across from them. A dark, plain Plymouth. The DRIVER gets out. Crewcut, white shirt and black tie, a gold badge and cuffs clipped to his belt buckle. There's another man in the passenger seat. Hard to make out through the watery reflection of trees in the glass. Hard to tell whether he's wearing a priest's collar or a turtleneck. The kids look at the badge. The Driver crooks a finger at them, wriggles it toward his cheat until they step over.
Let me ask you something. He looks from the sidewalk to the stick in Dave's hand.
You brats think it's okay to destroy municipal property? No answer. The Driver cups a hand behind his ear.
What's that?
No, sir.
No, sir.
No.
No what?
Sir...
You're the hard case of the group, huh? A pack of punks, huh? The Driver looks at Sean.
You live around here? Not intimidated, Sean points at the house behind them.
Right there. The Driver's eyes flicker up toward the house. For just an instant we see the fear and doubt in them. Then, deciding, he looks hard at Dave. Dave is near tears.
How 'bout you? Where do you live, son?
Rester Street.
Your mother home? Dave starts to cry. He nods.
We're going to go have a talk with her. Tell her what her punk kid's been up to. The Driver opens the back door of the Plymouth.

Get in. Dave doesn't move, looks at Jimmy. Sean leans out, notices the trash collected on the floor of the back seat. A strange, lost moment. The spell is broken as the Driver slaps his hand on the roof of the car.
Get the fuck inside! Bawling, Dave climbs in. The Driver points a finger at Jimmy and Sean.

Go tell your mothers what you've been up to. And don't let me catch you shits ruining my sidewalks again. The street goes mute with the SLAMMING of CAR DOORS. And then the car is driving off. Dave looks back at them out the window, his head darkened by distance and shadows. And then he's gone. Leaving Sean and Jimmy behind. In the b.g., VOICES, each more panicked than the last.
Weren't there three of you? Where's Dave?
The cops took Dave? What cops?
Oh my God. Oh my God. Dave.
Damaged goods. Even if they find him alive, he'll never be the same.
Dinged and cracked with twenty years of age. There are the names: Jimmy, Sean and D-A. Forever.
COME OFF the sidewalk to allow a MAN, wearing a Red Sox cap, late 30s, walking down the sidewalk with an eight- year-old boy (MICHAEL) wearing a little league uniform.
You took some good swings today.
Dad, I struck out.
Good swings though. That's what counts.
I'll never be a good ballplayer.
Hey, you're my son. Me. Dave Boyle, star shortstop of Don Bosco High School 1978 to 1982. You're going to be a great ballplayer. Michael's not so sure. Dave sees something ahead, points.
See that gutter drain? I used to play on this street when I was a kid. That drain used to swallow every ball we had. They start walking again, Michael listening eagerly.
Baseballs, street hockey balls, pinkies. If we could get the manhole cover off, there'd be a thousand balls down there.
Really? Let's try. As they near it, Dave spots the sidewalk square with the names in it. His good mood shifts a bit.
The Driver/cop slamming his palm on the hood of the Plymouth. Young Dave blinking back tears. Dave looks at his son, finally answers...
Maybe tomorrow. Let's get home before Mom starts to worry. They continue. As Dave looks back over his shoulder...

Forty years old. Sitting at a small desk surrounded by shelved stock: cigarettes, corn flakes, soda... Going over some order sheets, Jimmy's lost in thought. Different from when he was a kid, this is a 1,000 yard stare.  Beyond, through a half-open curtain, a CASH REGISTER RINGS, a couple kids working behind the counter. One of the clerks, PETE, 21, steps into the back.
Hey, Jimmy. Jimmy. He waves a hand in front of Jimmy's face.
Earth to Mr. Marcus. Jimmy snaps back to reality.
What do you want now, Pete?
Like I'm Mr. Needy all of a sudden. We're out of Marlboros and Winstons are looking grim.
So?
So that's lost profit. And more profits means I get a raise. Pete grabs a carton of cigarettes and heads out.

If the Surgeon General calls, you're my alibi. As Pete exits, Jimmy tries to focus on his order forms. Then KATIE is in the door looking at him. Nineteen, beautiful, Jimmy's daughter. She smiles as she watches him. He finally feels her eyes on him.
Going out tonight with Eve and Diane. And it's seven-thirty.
Don't be out late. It's your sister's first communion tomorrow. Christ, I sound like, I don't know...
Someone's father?
Yeah. Not mine, but somebody's. She leans in, kisses him on the cheek.
Later, Daddy. He watches her breeze out. Finally...
Later...
The BELL TINGLES as Katie walks out the front door. Humming to herself. In a great mood. She gets into her car.
Katie STARTS the CAR, nearly screams as someone sits up from the back seat. Then she recognizes:
Brendan. You scared the shit out of me. In the back seat BRENDAN HARRIS. Nineteen, he loves Katie Marcus like crazy. Brendan is an anthem for her.
Sorry. But I didn't want your dad to see me waiting.
He sees you sneaking into my car, he'll shoot you... And they're kissing. Like nineteen-year-olds.
(between breaths) What'll he do if he sees this?
Shoot you -- then kill you.
It's been six hours. I had to see you. As the passion increases, Katie suddenly breaks off.
I'm going to be late for Diane and Eve.
Tomorrow. Like we planned.
Tomorrow... They kiss again. Brendan ducks at the STORE BELL. It's a customer exiting.
Drop me around the corner. Katie laughs, drives. As the car turns the corner, we look up to the TOBIN BRIDGE. A gloomy old erector set spanning the Mystic River. THUMPING with the passing CARS.
Southbound lanes swarming with state police. The sight of a road-rage killing. Absolutely senseless.

He kept cutting me off. He kept cutting me off. SEAN DEVINE is here, now a detective with the staties. Grown up into a good-looking adult. He looks down at the tenements of Faneuil Heights and the East Bucky Flats. He's joined by his partner, WHITEY POWERS.
Guy won't stop confessing. We should pull a lawyer out of one of these B.M.W.s. Sean keeps staring down over the rail.
What'cha looking at?
My old neighborhood. A FEMALE TROOPER joins them. Her uniform not drab enough to hide how sexy she is. She stares straight at Sean.
We're done, Sean, but I can stick around if you need anything.  10.
No. We're fine.
A few of us are going to the Can Tab after.
I don't think so, Jan. Thanks. Disappointed, she heads off. Whitey watches her ass.
The wife left you, what, six months ago.
So?
So, Jenny Coughlin there, Jenny with the bod', the voice, the cuffs, the girl makes gay guys reconsider their orientation.
What's your point?
She is trying to bed you and you don't even blink.
I'm married, Whitey.
You haven't even talked to Lauren in six months.
She calls all the time.
And doesn't speak. Weirdest fucking thing I ever heard. Sean looks back out at the neighborhood.
One of these days the phone'll ring and she'll talk. I'll pick it up and she'll tell me why she left.  11.

Maybe she's waiting for you to say something. INT. McGILL'S BAR -- JUKEBOX -- NIGHT Where DIANE CESTRA drops a quarter in the slot. Pressing D-3, she looks back and smiles at her friends, EVE PIGEON and Katie Marcus. It's "Brown Eyed Girl" as VAN MORRISON starts: "Hey where did we go...?"
Diane unsteadily rejoins her friends. A girl's night out as they laugh, swig beer and sing-a-long with the music.
Dave Boyle sits hunched over a beer with a FRIEND, watching the Red Sox game on the TV.
Come on. Double play. At the sound of a cheer (not for the Sox), the Friend looks back over his shoulder, nudges Dave in the ribs.

You believe those chicks? As Dave turns to follow his gaze... Katie and Eve have climbed onto the bar, dance on top of it. Katie the class of the two. Some of the guys cheer, others watch with a sad yearning, know it's not for them. Dave cocks his head, watches Katie. Smiles to himself as her hair falls over her eyes like a veil.
Ain't that Jimmy Marcus's girl?
Yeah... We CLOSE ON Dave as he seems suddenly lost in the moment.
I remember when she was a kid.  12.
CELESTE BOYLE, 37, in her nightgown, leans against the door frame, looking in at her sleeping son Michael. She looks sad. At the click of the front door lock, she looks up.
Dave's closing it shut behind him when Celeste steps around the corner, concern still overriding anger.
Dave, it's three in the morning. Where have you been? I was -- She stops short as she sees there's blood all over him. He stands there embarrassed, like he was ten years old.
What happened?
I tucked up. The guy tried to mug me, right? So, so I swung on him. And he sliced me. He clutches at his side. Celeste sees that it's crimson.
(stepping forward) Jesus, Dave, you have to go to the hospital.
No, no. It's not that deep. It just bled like hell.
Dave, shirt off, holds his arm up, grimaces as Celeste dabs hydrogen peroxide on a sweeping gash along his rib cage.

I'm walking to my car and this guy comes up to me, asks for a light. I say I don't smoke. Guy says neither does he. So my heart starts clocking a buck fifty ‘cause there's no one around but me and him.  13.
Oh God.
That's when I see the knife and he says, "Your wallet or your life, bitch. I'm leaving with one of 'em.,
That's what he said?
Yeah. So, so then I try to brush past him and that's when he slices me. Celeste, can I tell the fucking story? She touches his cheek.
I'm sorry, baby. He kisses her hand.
I went fucking nuts on him, babe. I went off. I bashed his head on the parking lot. I, I might have killed him, honey.
Killed him? Dave nods. He's serious. Celeste looks at him. Eyes wide, face pale and sweaty. His breath starts to get a little ragged as he looks back. He's really scared.
It makes you feel alone. Hurting someone.
But you had to. Celeste embraces him. Over her shoulder:
It makes you feel... alien. Celeste looks at him, suddenly filling with strength.
Baby, you hop in the shower. (beat) I'll take care of your clothes.  14. Dave's not sure what that means. Neither are we.
Yeah?
Yeah.
Jimmy looks tough even when he's sleeping. His wife ANNABETH snoozes beside him. The bedside clock reads: 6:02. The PHONE starts to RING. Jimmy answers, bleary.
Yeah?
(over phone) I'm in the weeds here at the store, Jimmy. I need some help. Jimmy looks at the clock.
You and Katie can't handle six, how you going to handle eight when the first church crowd comes in?
That's the thing, Katie ain't here.
No? Hold on. Jimmy rolls to his feet. MOVE WITH him as he walks down...
The Sunday paper's still bundled, doughnut guy's honking his horn. He looks in her room. Her bed is empty and made.
I'll be there in ten minutes, Pete. Call Sal and see if he can make it by eight instead of ten.  15.
Jimmy pulls on his clothes. Annabeth watches from bed.
She no-shows at work, what if she no- shows at church?
I'm sure she'll make it.
Yeah. She's going to screw up this day, too.
What other day has she screwed up lately? Annabeth puts up her hands, doesn't want to fight.
You got two other daughters. Don't forget it.
One hour. I'll still be back before anyone gets out of bed.

Jimmy arrives to a morning rush. Folks coming off the night shift: Cops, nurses from St. Regina's and a few working girls, all coming off the same battlefield together. Pete looks up, smiles in relief as Jimmy takes up a position by the cash register and lottery machine. Jimmy punches out tickets, RINGS UP at the REGISTER. He also takes the phone off the wall behind him, dials.
(into phone) Hey, Drew, it's Jimmy. Sorry to wake you, I'm looking for Katie.
I think she's here, yeah. Lemme go check. Hold on. Jimmy's relieved. First time he even knew he was worried. As he bags a sale, smiles across at a customer.  16.
Sorry. It was Diane Cestra slept over. But no Katie. Eve said Katie dropped them off at one. Didn't say where she was going.
Okay, man, I'll track her down.
She seeing anyone maybe?
Nineteen-year-old girls, Drew? Who could keep a tally?
That's the cold truth. As Jimmy hangs up the phone, the BELL over the door RINGS and the first Sunday mass crowd rolls in. A shitload of blue hair old ladies. Pete looks over at Jimmy.
Welcome to hell... As they surge toward the counter in a wave.
As the blue hairs exit, the CASH REGISTER DING is replaced by CHURCH BELLS RINGING.
Jimmy pulls another pot of coffee from the brewer. Pete appears from out front.
I'll take the hookers over the old ladies any day. Mind if I step out back and grab a smoke?
Fuck, Pete, smoke the whole pack.  17.

The BELL RINGS. Jimmy looks up as Brendan Harris and his little brother Silent Ray enter. Ray carries his street hockey stick, a blankness living in his face. Brendan clocks Jimmy with a brief look of surprise before turning down an aisle. He talks to his brother with sign language. His brother's hands flying back answers.
(frowns ) Help you, Brendan?
Uh, no, Mr. Marcus, just getting some of that tea my mom likes.
Barry's. Next aisle over.
Oh thanks. Hands fly again as Brendan and Silent Ray move an aisle over. As Pete returns from his smoke.
What time's Sal getting here?
Any time now. Jimmy sighs, looks out the front window. Brendan comes to the counter with his tea. Pete steps over.
That it, Brendan?
And a Globe. While Jimmy is preoccupied and as Pete RINGS UP the sale.
So's, ah, I thought Katie worked on Sundays.
You sweet on my man's daughter, Brendan?  18.
(laughs ) No, no, no. I was just wondering, you know, because usually I see her here.
Oh... Not too happy to pick up Jimmy's attention, Brendan gets his change and starts out.
Nice seeing you. Come on, Ray. Ray, his back to his brother when he spoke, turns and starts after him. Jimmy stares after them as they go.
Can I ask you something, Jimmy?
Shoot.
Why do you hate that kid so bad?
It's not hate, man. But come on, don't you find that mute little fucker a little spooky?
Not Silent Ray. Brendan. Jimmy looks over at Pete.

Nice kid. Uses sign language with his brother even if he doesn't have to. It's like, so he won't feel alone. But, Jimmy, you look at Brendan like you're two steps from slicing off his nose and feeding it to him.
No. Really?
Straight up.  19. Jimmy looks back out the window at the receding brothers, hands flying. Then old man Sal crosses the view, headed for the store. Jimmy starts untying his work apron.
Here comes Sal. About fucking time, too...
The tenements, the Tobin Bridge, beat-up baseball diamonds and rusty playgrounds. OVER it all, a 911 Operator answers a call:
9-1-1, police services. What is the nature of your emergency?
There's like this car with blood in it and, ah, the door's open -
What's the location of the car?

Uh, Sydney Street in the Flats. By Pen Park. Me and my friend found it. The AERIAL VIEW PASSES OVER Pen Channel, the abandoned drive-in screen on one side of the park and then Pen Park itself. A littered, depressing site.
Son, what's your name?
(to someone else) He wants to know her name.
Your name. What's your name?

We're so fucking out of here. Good luck. CLICK. We've OVER the Sydney Street entrance to the park. There's a car down there, door open, front tires against the curb. As we CONTINUE PAST it and INTO the mostly abandoned houses across the way...  20.
Dispatch, this is unit thirty-three. We're going to need a crime scene tech or two and you might want to notify homicide.
Have you found a body, thirty-three? Over.
No, but looks of this car, we'll find one sooner or later.

Blue sawhorses stamped °BOSTON POLICE DEPARTMENT® cordon off the scene. The crime scene services van is parked further down. Sean Devine pulls up in an unmarked, gets out. He's met by his partner Whitey.

Hey, bad boy. This should be the city's but... (points) Park's reservation land. State jurisdiction, not city. If the body's in there, it's our case. Police are already walking through the underbrush.
(wincing) How much evidence you think they've destroyed so far? As they start toward the car, one of the cops adds local color as we hear him talk to his buddies.
The Parker Hill vic, right? Walked into the E.R. at M.G.H. on his own, steak knife sticking out of his collarbone, asking the nurse where they keep the Coke machine round this bitch.
She tell him? They all laugh, but Sean. It's too goddamn early.  21.
What do we got on the car so far?
We found the reg in the glove box. Owner is Katherine Marcus. Sean reacts hard to the name.
Shit.
You know her?
Maybe. Might be the daughter of a guy I know.
We found a wallet and license ina backpack on the floor. She was nineteen.
Fuck. That's her.
Is it a problem? You close with the guy? Sean waves it off. He's staying on the case.
When we were kids. Now? Just a hello around the neighborhood.
Nineteen... Fuck, man. He's in for a world of hurt.
Her hands pressed together, dressed in a white dress with a white veil. Walking up the aisle in a procession of twenty other children. First communion.
Stand with their other daughter, Sara. Look back to watch their daughter come up the aisle. As Nadine's about to pass them, Annabeth whispers:  22.
Do not make her laugh. As Nadine passes, she chances a look over at her father. He waves from his hip, wiggles his eyebrows. Nadine smiles huge. Annabeth digs an elbow into his ribs.
What? As she continues to the altar, Jimmy looks back over his shoulder. Really hoping to see Katie arrive at the last minute. But she's not going to make it.
Door was ajar when we found it. Headlights on. You got blood on the driver door speaker...
Sean looks the car over, puts the initial crime together.

More blood on top of the steering wheel and around a bullet hole punched through the driver's seat back at shoulder level. As more police arrive to search, Sean looks at a fresh dent in the driver's door, past to the weeds, takes a stab.

Perp stood outside the car. The Marcus girl slams him with the door. Perp gets a round off, hits her in the shoulder, maybe the biceps? She runs for it. (points into park) Through those trampled weeds.
As Nadine solemnly receives her first communion. Annabeth, near tears, leans into Jimmy, whispers in his ear.

Our baby. My God, Jimmy, our baby.  23. Jimmy puts his arm around her, kisses the side of her head. As she leans into him a little more... FLASHBACK --— CELLAR Young Dave curled up whimpering on a pile of rags. Looking up in terror as a DOOR BANGS open at the top of the stairs. And as feet start ominously down...

The man, waking up with a start in his bed. INT. BOYLE APARTMENT -- KITCHEN -- DAY Michael sits at the table eating cereal. Celeste is at the counter flipping through the last of three different newspapers. She looks up as Dave enters, yawning, just rolled out of bed. He goes to the refrigerator without an apparent care in the world. CELESTE Dave... He looks over, clocks the look on her face. He steps over.
(low) There's nothing in the papers. I checked three times.
It was late. Real late. He kisses her forehead. She manages a smile.
Morning, Mikey. You up for hitting some whiffle ball?

A nylon triangle hangs from a branch. Just under a footbridge over Pen Channel. The CSS Tech pinches it off with a pair of tweezers. It's got blood on it. Sean and Whitey crouch by the arch. There's a woman's shoe there along with several similar footprints.  24.
I'd say she might've hid here a bit. Killer shows and she bolts to the other side, takes off running again. Sean looks out to where the water in the channel widens out.
Better call some divers while we're at it.
The kids flow outside through the front of the church, the adults following behind. Nadine spots her father, makes a break for him.
Daddy, Daddy! Jimmy scoops her in his arms.
Baby!
This dress itches.

It's itching me and I'm not even wearing it. Jimmy looks over his shoulder, smiles at Annabeth and Sara. They beam back. A moment of perfect happiness, until... A state POLICE CRUISER SLAMS around the corner of Buckingham Avenue. Jimmy whips around, matches as it goes wide into the left lane of Roseclair, rear TIRE SLAPPING the median strip, SIREN SLICING the morning air. It's followed an instant later by a black unmarked, cutting the ninety-degree turn at forty miles an hour. Two more cop cars zip under the overpass, take the entrance road into Pen Park. Jimmy lowers Nadine to the ground.  25. And he knows, feels it in his blood with a sudden mean certainty, a sense of things falling miserably into place.
Katie...

Looks like a riot waiting room. Cops, in the bushes, cops at the sawhorses, cops everywhere. K-9 German shepherds being walked out of a van. The crowd of onlookers growing. Jimmy steps up, is spotted by ED DEVEAU who's opening a bag of M&Ms with his teeth. As a POLICE HELICOPTER BUZZES by.
Hey, Jimmy.
What's up, Ed?
They got Sydney blocked off, Crescent, all the way to Dunboy. Boo Bear Durkin said he saw frogmen going into the Pen. Why you all decked out?
So what the hell you doing here?

Just curious I guess. Jimmy spots the clot of cops around a car, moves laterally for a better view. He gets it, sees it's Katie's. Jimmy starts forward, pushes through one end of the sawhorse, is almost there before two cops block him. As they babble official speak...
That's my daughter's cart
Sean looking for something, anything. Whitey steps over.  26.
We got dogs sniffing something by the old drive-in screen. Want to take a walk over? Sean nods. His WALKIE-TALKIE SURGES TO LIFE.
Trooper Devine.
(into walkie) Yeah, go ahead.
We got a guy out on Sydney, says he's the father of the girl.
Shit... (into walkie) You got a psychologist on scene yet?
En route.
He's asking for you, Devine. Says he knows you. Sean looks to Whitey who just shrugs.
He's not taking no for an answer. And he's got some guys with him.
What guys?
Scary-looking guys.
The Savage brothers. Christ. (into walkie) I'm on my way.
Jimmy's there with three of the Savage brothers: NICK, VAL and Kevin. His brothers-in-law. Jail-yard stares and hair triggers. They shout across the barrier at the cops.  27.
That's our niece in there, you dumb prick pieces of shit!
Hey. We're doing our job.
All due respect, the doughnut shop's that way. Jimmy standing a little alone, watching. Finally:
Val, ease up! Nick. Nickie. Take Kevin and go to Drew Pigeon's. Talk to his daughter and her friend. Katie was out with them last night.
(nodding) Kevin, let's go!
And hey, these girls are friends. Don't get hard on them, but get answers. As Nick and Kevin head off, Sean arrives, greeting Jimmy with as big a smile as he can muster.
Jimmy, hey, man.
Is she in there, Sean?
We don't know. All we're doing right now is looking.
So let us in. We can help look. Sean doesn't even look at Val, just keeps his eyes on Jimmy.
Sorry. As soon as I know anything, you'll know.
That's my daughter's car.  28.
I know. I --
(panic rising) My daughter's car. It's got blood in it. They brought fucking dogs in. Why do you got dogs looking for my daughter, Sean?
Because we're looking. Okay, Jimmy? Right now all she is is missing. Okay? As Jimmy nods, Sean's WALKIE CRACKLES TO LIFE right.
Trooper Devine, we got something.
Say again.
Sergeant Powers said you need to get in here. Uh, ASAP, like right now.
Your location?
The drive-in screen. And, man, it's a fucking mess. Sean looks back at Jimmy who's just about coming out of his skin. Sean looks to the cops.
Don't let him through. As Sean hurries off, Jimmy steps back alongside Val.
You still got those bolt cutters in your trunk?
Guy's gotta make a living, Jim. Jimmy goes the other way, Val following.  29.
Celeste washes dishes, scrubbing away like it means something. A portable TV on the counter. Suddenly: the TV newsroom.

We interrupt to bring you a breaking story. A massive search is under way for a woman missing in the Buckingham Flats. A news chopper POV. The car and park and police below. Celeste watches transfixed, soap dripping from her hands.

All we know so far is that there are signs of foul play in a car found abandoned outside Pen Park. Police have... As the anchor drones, Celeste goes to the window, takes a vertiginous look into the yard below. Dave is playing ball with Michael. As they laugh and pal around, Celeste looks momentarily ill.

Steps lead down to a door on the side of the screen. CSS flashbulbs pop. Whitey looks in, jots notes. An assistant MEDICAL EXAMINER is down on his knees looking at something. Plus a platoon of uniformed troopers and Boston PD blues. A BABY-FACED COP stares away from the action, being comforted by his partner as Sean passes on his way in.

I never saw anything like it. Man, this is... this is... Sean sees the blood, already circled, on the steps leading down. A path is made for him. As he reaches the door, Whitey looks back, meets Sean's gaze, looks ten years older. Sean's view widens as he sees between the ME and CSS tech. A body is scrunched there, the space between the walls no more than three feet wide.  30. Katie Marcus sits with her back against the wall on the right, her feet pushed up hard on the wall to the left. Like a fetus in some horrific womb. A torn sock hangs around her left ankle, a simple black shoe with a flat heel is on her right foot. Her jacket is torn, her pants mud-stained. Blood is everywhere. Like a red rain, it's in her hair, dots her cheeks, stains her clothes in red strings. Katie's knees are pressed to her chest, her right elbow propped on her right knee, a clenched fist up by her ear trying to keep some awful sound at bay. Her eyes are clenched shut as tight as her fist. Stop it, just stop it, the body says. Stop it, please. Sean steps in, crouches. Whitey fills the space behind him.
That her? As gently as he can, Sean uses his forefinger to move back a heavy strand of hair. He looks at Katie a moment.
Yeah...
We'll have the father do a positive at the morgue.
Blood's from a split on the crown of her head. She was beaten with some kind of stick. But that didn't kill her. She was shot a second time. Looks like a .38. Sean hasn't really heard any of it.

What the fuck am I going to tell him. Hey guess what, Jimmy? God said you owed another marker. He came to collect. Sudden SHOUTS from outside, the K-9 DOGS BARK like mad. Sean springs up. As he and Whitey turn outside.  31.

Eight uniforms and two plainclothes converge on Jimmy and Val as they burst from the trees. Val goes down snarling almost right away. But Jimmy's too quick. He's almost to the screen when he stumbles. A young trooper, all head and high school tight-end, body-tackles him, lands on top of him. As he pins Jimmy's arm back...
Hey! Hey! It's the father. Just pull him back. As Sean turns back to the screen:
Sean! Look at me, Sean! Sean looks back at him. Jimmy arches up under the young cop's weight. Another cop helps hold him.

You find her? Is it her? Is it? Sean is motionless. He holds Jimmy's eyes with his own, locking them until Jimmy's surging stare sees what Sean has just seen. And he knows it's over, his worst fear realized. And Jimmy screams. Love and rage in equal quantities. It shreds the birds from the trees. It ECHOES into the Pen Channel. Ropes of spit shoot from his mouth. Screaming. Sean turns away, looks back in at Katie. It's awful.

Jimmy sits in a straight-back wooden chair. Waiting, head back, hands folded. He looks up at FOOTSTEPS. Annabeth is shown in by a young officer. Jimmy rises. She's still wearing her lavender dress from the communion. She steps into his arms, presses her face into his chest.
No one said anything. Right?
What do you mean, baby?  32.
You haven't seen her yet, right? It might not be her, right? Jimmy doesn't answer, doesn't know what to say. Annabeth looks up at him. Desperate, wretched with hope.
Jimmy... Jimmy, please. Please.
Please what, honey? What?
Oh, please, Jimmy. No. No. Sobbing, she crumbles into him.

PUSH IN ON Katie. She lies on a metal table. Her eyes are closed and she's missing a shoe. Jimmy enters from the other way. Sean a step behind him. Jimmy stops short, opens his mouth to speak, but nothing comes out. Sean puts a hand on the small of his back.
Yeah, that's her. That's Katie. That's my daughter.
Sean sits across from Jimmy and Annabeth. A beat of surreal silence before Whitey arrives with four coffees.
Fresh-brewed.

We need to work a timeline. It's the details, the little things that can make a case. Things you forget after a day or two. Annabeth nods that she understands. Jimmy's a little in shock. Lost a moment, then he looks to Sean.
You ever think how one choice can change your life? (MORE )
I heard Hitler's mother almost aborted him but bailed at the last minute. You know?
What do you mean, Jimmy?
Say you or me got in that car instead of Dave Boyle.
What car?
I'm losing you here, Jimmy.

If I'd got in that car, life would be a different thing. My first wife, Marita, Katie's mother? She was beautiful. Regal. You know the way some Latin women can be? And she knew it. You had to have balls to even go near her. And I did. Eighteen years old, the two of us, and she was carrying Katie. Here's the thing, Sean, if I had gotten in that car, I most likely would've ended up a basket case. I never would have had the juice to ask out Marita and we never would've had Katie. And Katie, then, would never have been murdered. You see what I'm saying?
You ever see Dave around?
He married my cousin. Celeste. Sean nods again. Whitey finally gets things on track.
What time did Katie get home from work yesterday?
Around four-thirty.
Anything unusual? Out of the ordinary about her?  34.
No. She sat with me and the girls while we ate. She was having dinner with her friends. Whitey checks his pad.
Eve Pigeon and Diane Cestra?
(nodding) Katie talked to Nadine about her Communion, then she was on the phone in her room a bit, and then, about eight, she left.
Do you know who she talked to?
No.
Would you mind if we subpoenaed the phone company records to that line? Annabeth looks over at Jimmy.
No. Go ahead.
Mr. Marcus, you spent a good part of Saturday with your daughter at the store, correct?
Yes and no. I was mostly in back.
You remember anything odd? A confrontation with a customer?
No. She was herself. She was happy. She --
What?
No, nothing.  35.
The littlest thing is something right now.

When she was little, right after her mother had died, I had just gotten out of prison and I could never leave her alone. Whether she ended up crying or not, she'd get this look. Like she was preparing to never see you again. For a few seconds on Saturday, she looked at me that way. Whitey starts to write this down. His shock
Hey, it was just a look.
It's info. I collect it until a few pieces fit. Little things. You say you were in prison?
I'm just asking.
Sixteen years ago. Two years at Deer Island for robbery. Is that going to help you catch my daughter's killer? I mean, I'm just asking. dissolving, Jimmy stares hard at Whitey.
Okay, let's forget it and get back to the point. Okay?
The point.
Outside that look Katie gave you, was there anything else? Jimmy takes his convict-in-the-yard stare off Whitey, sips some coffee, does his genuine best to think.
Um, this kid... No, that was this morning.  36.
What? Remember, little things.
Neighborhood, kid, Brendan Harris, came in this morning, asked if Katie was around, like he expected to see her. But they barely knew each other.
You're sure? Could they have been dating?
No.
Why are you so sure?
Hey, Sean, what the fuck? You're going to grill me? A father knows.
Mrs. Marcus? Who was she seeing?
No one right now. As far as we know. I mean... knew. The past/present tense is all it took. As Annabeth fights back tears, Jimmy squeezes her hand.
I'll answer everything you got tomorrow, but we got to go. We got two girls waiting at home wondering where their sister is.

There'll be a trooper downstairs to drive you home. If you think of anything, give us a call. Whitey hands Jimmy his card. Jimmy nods good-bye, helps Annabeth away. Sean and Whitey watch as they head off.
He said you almost got in some car when you were kids. What was that about?  37.
We, shit, well, there was this car. Me and Jimmy and a kid named Dave Boyle were playing in front of my house. And this car came up the street and took Dave away.
Abduction?
Guys pretended to be cops. Convinced Dave to get in the car. They had him for four days before he managed to get away.
They catch the guys?
One died, the other got busted about a year later and went the noose route in his cell.
Your buddy, Marcus. Moment I laid eyes on him, I knew he'd done time. They never lose the tension, you know? It settles in their shoulders.
He just lost his daughter, man. Maybe that's what settled in his shoulders.
No. That's in his stomach. Notice how he kept grimacing? Seen it a million times. The shoulders, though, that's prison.
As Young Dave desperately pounds. Trying to get out.

Along the Mystic River. Dave Boyle walks, hands thrust in his pockets. Prostitutes blend in the shadows of doorways, lean into the windows of IDLING CARS. Some take a half-step in the streetlight to show Dave what they got.  38. But he continues forward, not interested. Last of all, a kid, a boy, fifteen at the most. Lighting a smoke, he looks up, smiles around the cigarette. Dave stops. The kid's eyes suddenly widen in recognition and he bolts. Dave follows a few steps, but the kid's already disappeared into the darkness.
I just want to talk to you!
Two uniformed TROOPERS search. Under the mattress, through drawers. We hear GIRLS CRYING in the next room. They look up, embarrassed, as Jimmy looks in.
You guys almost done?
Almost, sir.
Find anything?
Her bankbook. Did you know she closed her account two days ago? Withdrew seven hundred dollars?
No. No I didn't. As the troopers go back to work and Jimmy walks away...

Storefronts shut down across the street. A rumbling stillness has taken over the area. Jimmy steps out on the porch of his three-decker. He sits on the steps. Closing his eyes, he leans back, listens, as the tears of ANNABETH AND HIS DAUGHTERS drift down.
Jimmy... Jimmy doesn't hear it at first.  39.
Hey, aim. Jimmy opens his eyes. Standing at the bottom of the steps is Dave. It takes Jimmy a blink or two to recognize him.
Hey, Dave.
I wasn't going to talk to you tonight, but I was out for a walk and saw you sitting here.
It's okay.
So you know, me and Celeste, the whole neighborhood, if you need anything, anything, we're here.
Appreciate it, Dave. A moment. Dave manages a little smile, a wave.
I'll leave you alone. As Dave starts away.
Dave... Dave stops, looks back hopefully.
You know how it is. Irish family. Catholics. How it'll be tomorrow.
House full of people all day.
Yeah. All Annabeth has are those ham- fisted brothers of hers. If Celeste could come over and give her a hand...
Sure, Jimmy. You got it. Dave gives another little wave, starts on his way.  40.
Lieutenant Friel stands before a room of eight detectives.
Powers, where are we so far?

Time of death roughly one-fifteen to one- thirty A.M. No sign of sexual assault. Cause of death most likely the gunshot wound to the back of the head, not the trauma from the beating she took. B.P.D. officers are on a house-to-house along Sydney to see if anyone heard anything.
What else?
We're waiting on ballistics... The lack of footprints pisses me off. It rained. Still, she left some, but the perp? Nothing.
What else?
She and her friends were bar-hopping. Four places. We're interviewing everyone might've seen or talked to them.
One other thing. Backpack in her car had pamphlets on Las Vegas and a list of Vegas hotels.
Doesn't sound like much. (looking at Sean) What do you say, Devine?
We'll get the guy, sir. Friel nods, heads out.
Four years of college and that's all you could come up with?  4l.
It made him happy, didn't it?

Annabeth and Celeste at the stove, cooking bacon and eggs. Neither talks, but they're happy for each other's company. A HUBBUB of VOICES from the hallway, up which Jimmy walks. Jimmy trades smiles with Celeste, then looks at Annabeth.
You need anything, baby? I can work the stove a bit. Annabeth shakes her head, but doesn't look at him.
No, I'm fine. Jimmy looks at Celeste as if to say: Is she?
We got things covered, Jimmy. Celeste watches as Jimmy looks at his wife. He reaches, wipes a bead of sweat off Annabeth's cheek with his finger.
Don't.
Look at me.
I can't. Jimmy, if I look at you I'll lose it and I can't lose it with all these people here... Okay?
Okay, baby, okay.
I just don't want to lose it again. Celeste wishes she could crawl off, feels like she's looking at them naked, intimate before her.  42.
An old lady, a busybody. She has one eye on the TV, the other on Sean and Whitey.
I heard a car hit something.
Hit what, ma'am, another car?
Oh no, not loud like that.
Like hitting the curb?
Yes, maybe. And then it stalled and someone said, 'hi.'
Someone said, 'hi'?
Hi. And then there was a loud crack.
Did you ever look out the window, Mrs. Prior?
Yes, maybe. No. I was in my dressing gown by then. I don't stand in the window in my dressing gown.
The voice that said, 'hi,' was it male or female?
Female, I think. Sean looks at Whitey.
Sounds like she knew the shooter.  43.

A throng already gathered. Celeste comes out to fill coffee cups. She looks across the room at Dave who's sandwiched between some of the Savage brothers. He sees her, smiles wanly. Very out of his element. And Celeste can feel his aloneness. As she smiles back... The DOORBELL RINGS. Jimmy gets it. It's his father-in- law, THEO SAVAGE, a case of beer on each shoulder.
Jimmy.
Theo. Jimmy takes one of the cases, as Theo steps inside.
How's my daughter? How's Annabeth holding up?
She's trying, Theo.
(re: beer) Let's get these on ice. You got some coolers?
Jimmy shakes a bag of ice into a beer cooler; Theo watches.
How you handling this so far? Jimmy looks up at Theo, not really in the mood.
Hasn't really sunk in, Theo.
Gonna hurt like hell when it does. When my Jane died? I was no good for six months. But my kids were all grown up. I had that luxury. You, you got domestic responsibilities?
Domestic responsibilities?
Yeah, you know, you gotta take care of my daughter and those little girls. They got to be your priority now.
You figured that might slip my mind, Theo?
Just needed to be said is all. You'll carry on. 'Cause you're a man. I said to Annabeth, your wedding day, said you got yourself a real old school man there --
Like they put her in a bag.
What's that?
That's what Katie looked like when I saw her in the morgue. Like someone put her in a bag and then had beaten the bag with pipes.
Yeah, well, I, uh --
Janey died in her sleep. All due respect and shit, but there you go. She went to bed and never woke up. Peaceful.
You don't need to talk about Janey --

My daughter though? Someone put a gun to her. She was murdered. And right about now they'll be starting the autopsy. Laying out scalpels and chest spreaders. And you want to talk to me about my domestic fucking responsibilities? Theo looks down, shuts up finally.  45.
Crying, holding each other. Eve's FATHER looks on, back behind Sean and Whitey.
Eve, just tell them what they need to know.
Who was she dating?
We already told the Savages.
The Savage brothers?
They were here yesterday.
Well, try us out, who was she dating?
No one special. Sean plays a hunch.
You guys had a good-bye dinner, didn't you?
(busted) What?
She was leaving town, wasn't she? Going to Las Vegas.
How do you know?
She closed her bankbook, had hotel phone numbers.
She wanted out of this dump. She wanted to start a new life.  46. At "life" they start crying again.
A nineteen-year-old girl doesn't go to Vegas alone. Who was she going with? Come on, Eve, who?
Brendan.
Brendan Harris?
Brendan Harris. Yeah.
Just Ray's kid? The one with a mute for a bother? Eve nods.
You got an address?

Jimmy sits on the deck. Sits by himself under the clothesline stretched across the porch. Sits beneath the flapping clothes. The sounds of the WAKE drift out as he stares up at the sky. Dave steps out. Unaware of Jimmy, he steps to the rail, lights a cigarette.
Hey, Dave.
(turns; surprised) Hey, Jimmy. Sorry. Came out for a smoke.
No, no, man. Sit down. Dave sits down alongside Jimmy, backs to the siding.
I haven't had a chance to talk to you all day. How you doing?  47.
How you doing? Jimmy shrugs. He sees that Dave's right hand is swollen.
What happened to your hand?
This? I was helping a buddy move a couch. Slammed it into the doorjamb. Jimmy tilts his head, looks at the badly-scraped knuckles, the bruised flesh between the fingers.
The ways you can manage to hurt yourself, right? Jimmy looks into his face, forgets his hand.
It's good to see you, man.
Yeah?
How are our girls holding up?
They're okay, I guess.
Celeste is a godsend. Thank her for me, okay? Dave nods. They sit there in silence a moment.
It's nice. Just sitting here.
Yeah. Jimmy jerks a thumb over his shoulder.
I couldn't take it anymore. Trying to find room in the fridge for all the food we're going to be throwing out in a few days.  48.
It's a lot of waste, huh?

But I can't let the things that happen the next few days get fucked up. Because then that's all anyone'll remember about her. Because, Katie, man, one thing you could say about her since she was little, that girl was neat. Dave looks like he's going to cry out of sympathy.
That first night out of the joint, after Marita died, I was more afraid of my little daughter than I ever was of being in prison. Fuck... Dave looks pained as the tears roll down Jimmy's cheeks.

I loved her the most, because when we sat in the kitchen that first night, we were the last two people on Earth. Forgotten and unwanted. And, Dave, I swear, it's starting to piss me off. I haven't cried yet for her. My own daughter and I can't even cry. Fuck...
Jim?
Yeah?
You're crying now.
(realizing) ) Damn...
Want me to leave you alone?
No, Dave. Just sit here a minute if that's cool.
Sure, Jim. That's cool.  49.
Maybe the most miserable woman alive. She chain-smokes Parliaments, watches as Sean and Whitey question her son.
When was the last time you saw Katie Marcus?
You don't think I hurt her, do you?
She isn't hurt, Brendan, she's dead.
I didn't kill her.
So again, when's the last time you saw her?
Friday night. About, like, eight or so?
About like eight, Brendan, or at eight? If it's settled in Jimmy's stomach, it's settled in Brendan's whole body.

About eight. We had a couple of slices at Hi-Fi. Then she had to go meet Eve and Diane. Brendan looks down. Esther crushes out her cigarette in a pile in the ashtray. Something still burns, a thin stream of smoke, corkscrewing up. As she lights another.
Brendan, Jimmy Marcus doesn't like you. Why?
I don't know. But he told Katie he never wanted her seeing me or any other Harris.
What? That thief thinks he's better than this family?  50.
He's not a thief.
He was a thief. Scumbag burglar. Daughter probably had the same bad gene. Count yourself lucky, Brea. Brendan withers under the harsh words.
Katie had brochures for Las Vegas. We heard she was going there. With you. As Esther rolls her eyes at the thought, Brendan nods his head. Yes. Esther flinches.
We were going to leave today. Get married when we got there. Brendan wipes the tears before they can fall.
I mean, that was the plan, right?
You were going to leave me? Without a word?
Ma, I --
Just like your father. Huh? At that moment, the front door opens and Silent Ray and his friend JOHN O'SHEA enter, skateboards under their arms.
This is my brother Ray and his friend John.
Hey, boys.
Hey. Ray doesn't respond.  51.
He don't speak. Father couldn't shut up, but his son is a mute. Oh, yeah, life's fucking fair. Ray's hands fly at Brendan and Brendan nods back.
Yeah, they're here about Katie. Go watch TV or something. As the boys ramble out.
Where were you between twelve-thirty and two this morning?
Asleep.
Can you confirm that, Mrs. Harris?
I can confirm he closed his door at ten and showed up for breakfast at nine. I can't confirm he didn't climb out the window and down the fire escape. Brendan just stares at the floor.
Brendan, we're going to ask you to take a polygraph. You up for that?
(nods; then) I loved her so much. I, I won't ever feel that again. I mean, it doesn't happen twice, right? He looks up, pain in his eyes you want to duck from.
It doesn't happen once, most cases.

It's quiet. Sounds like the crowd is gone. Celeste tidies in the kitchen. Busy work really. Wiping down the toaster, wiping down already clean counters. I'd rather be here than home work.  52. Jimmy enters, is surprised to see her.
Celeste. Celeste jumps, nearly shouts out.
Sorry, Jimmy. You surprised me.
What are you still doing here?
(nodding) I convinced her to take a pill. Girls are asleep, too. Jimmy's in here for a reason. He pours himself a shot of whiskey. Celeste watches him. With a wry smile.
Could I get one of those?
For the road. Then home.
I can stay over if you want. Sit up with Annabeth if she wakes up.
No. You've done enough. Jimmy hands her her shot, raises his.
To you and Dave. For being here for us. They knock back their shots. Celeste sets her glass down.
I'll come by tomorrow. First thing.
Good night. As she heads out, Jimmy picks up the bottle. About to pour another shot, decides not to. As he screws the cap back on --  53.

Sean sits on the sofa looking through a shoe box of old photos. Mostly him and his wife, Lauren. But there's an older, thicker Polaroid: him, Jimmy and Dave when they were kids. As he stares, BLEED IN the sound of KIDS LAUGHING, the sound of a CAR ROLLING, STOPPING. The PHONE RINGS.
Hello? No answer. A FLASH of a WOMAN'S HAND on the other end.
Oh Christ. Say something, Lauren. He waits, thumbs a picture of his wife. Finally:

I'm tired of wishing things made sense. Tired of caring about one dead girl because there'll be another one after her. And sending killers to jail is just sending them home. To the place they've been heading all their dumb, pathetic lives. And the dead are still dead. No response. Sean squeezes his eyes shut.
Jesus, I can't do this tonight. I can't do it. He waits a few more seconds, can almost hear her breathing.
Bye, baby. As he hangs up...
In bed, under the covers, trying to stay awake as his Dad tells him a bedtime story. Dave sits on the edge of the bed, speaking in a hushed tone.  54.

Because sometimes the man wasn't a man at all. He was the boy. The boy who'd escaped from wolves. An animal of the dusk. Invisible. Silent. Living in a world others never saw, a world of fireflies. Unseen except as a flare in the corner of your eye. Vanished by the time you turned your head toward it.'
Young Dave runs through the trees. Escaping. Looking like a boy, but sounding like an animal.
Dave looks over at Michael who's now fully asleep. Dave continues, softer now, even more to himself.
I just need to get my head right. Catch a nice long sleep and the boy will go back to his forest. Back to his fireflies.
Is he asleep? Dave looks up, sees Celeste in the doorway. Dave nods, joins Celeste in...
How's Jimmy and everybody?
Okay.
It's weird, took something like this for me and him to become friends again.
There's still nothing in the paper, Dave.
About what?  55.
About what?
Oh, I don't know, honey. Maybe I didn't hurt the guy as bad as I thought. And he was a mugger; he's not going to the hospital.
Right. Okay.

Anyhow, it doesn't matter, does it? I mean, Katie Marcus is dead, and that seems more important right now. Celeste nods. She starts to reach for him, stops. As she turns and disappears down the hall, Dave watches her go.

Jimmy sits under the clothesline, a pillow in his hand. As he breathes it in and out, we PAN OFF him to... The neighborhood spread out at night. Lights twinkle. Sounds are muted. And in the distance, the Mystic River flows. And over it, we hear:
Later, Daddy... And then...
I know in my soul I contributed to your death. I can feel it. But I don't know how.
You will... And as the CAMERA CLOSES ON the river...
Brendan Harris aced his polygraph. Four straight times.
Good. I didn't like him for it or want him for it.
Yeah, poor fucking kid. Whitey starts casting about his desk.
Ballistics should be in in a few hours. Meanwhile, we got that list of bar patrons. He finds it, hands Sean a list of about 100 names.
I'm sure they're all just dying to cooperate with the police.
(scanning list) Considering the crime, maybe.
(recognizes Dave Boyle) The same guy you were friends with as a kid? The car guy?
Could be.
He'd be a guy to talk to. He knows you, won't treat us like cops, clam up for no good reason.
The door opens and Dave starts down the front steps with Michael. He stops short as a black unmarked pulls up. Sean and Whitey get out. Sean recognizes Dave.
Dave Boyle. What's it been? Seven, eight years?  57.
Hey, Sean. Stepping forward, Sean shakes his hand. Dave grimaces.
This is my son. Michael.
Hey, Michael. I'm Sean, an old buddy of your dad.
Hi.
You still with the Staties?
Yeah. Homicide now. Actually, this is my partner.
Sergeant Powers. How you doing? Whitey sticks out his hand. Dave shakes it, again trying not to wince.
Dave, you got a minute, we'd love to ask you a couple quick questions.
Actually, I got to walk Michael to school, but I could be back in a few minutes.
Tell you what, we'll walk with you.
Uh, sure. They start walking.
I hear rents are rising.
They cut my dad's old house up into condos.  58.

Me and Michael walked by there the other day. There's got to be a way to stop them. Friend of mine said the other day, Sean, he said, what this neighborhood needs is a good fucking crime wave. That'd send property values back where they belong.
Girls keep getting murdered in Pen Park, Mr. Boyle; you might get your wish.
Dave. Call me Dave.
You said the 'f' word, Dad.
Walk up on ahead, Michael. Us guys have to talk. Michael sighs, takes a few steps ahead.
What's up, Sean?
You heard about Katie Marcus?
Yeah. I was at Jimmy's all day yesterday. Celeste's there now.
Who's Celeste?
My wife.
How's Jimmy doing? Dave's getting a bit frazzled with all the little questions.
Hard to tell. You know him.
The reason we came by --  59.
I saw her. Katie. I don't know if you know that. At McGill's. The night she died.
Well, yeah, Dave, that's why we're here. They were at a couple of bars that night. Your name showed up on a list of people who were in McGill's.
We hear she and her friends put on quite a show. Dancing on the bar. They were pretty drunk, huh?
Yeah, but it was harmless. They weren't stripping or nothing. They were just, nineteen, you know?
What time did they leave?
I left at one. They left maybe fifteen minutes before me.
So we'll say twelve-forty-five?
Sounds about right.
You see anything unusual that night? Anyone?
Like what?
Guy watching the girls? Guy with black hate in his eyes? Woman hater?
No. If they hadn't danced on the bar, it would've been business as usual, you know? Sean nods. They've reached the school.  60.
See you later, Dad.
Got your milk money?
Uh huh. Michael runs off to join his friends. An odd moment as Dave watches the laughing, happy kids.
God, I hated school.
Huh? Yeah, me, too.
I forgot to ask, sir. Where'd you go after you left McGill's?
Uh, home.
Home by one-fifteen would you say?
Roughly. Sure. An almost embarrassed silence until...
Good seeing you, Dave. Grab a beer sometime?
Yeah, Sean, I'd like that. Sean and Whitey start back down the sidewalk. Dave watches them go. Sean waves once over his shoulder and Dave finds himself waving back even though Sean can't see him.
Whitey and Sean exit with coffee.  61.
Starbuck's. You believe this crap? Same as Dunkin' Donuts, except five times the price. As they sip, something else is really bothering them.
You take away money or love or hate as possible motives, you're not left with much.
If this Marcus thing was random, I mean, shit...
Tell me about it. But the old lady, Prior, she didn't hear a scream. She heard a gunshot, and before that, a 'hi. Which means either the Marcus girl is pretty goddamn friendly or she knew him.
But she didn't just stop. She turns into the curb. Not too fast or she would've hopped it. Foot comes off the clutch, she stalls.
She says hi, guy shoots her.
She slams her door into him, makes a run for it.
But what makes her swerve without hitting the brakes?
Something in the road.
Maybe. Look, Marcus girl couldn't have weighed more than one-ten. How hard could she have hit the guy to get a head start into the park?
Either he wasn't back on his heels or, he doesn't weigh so much himself.  62.
Which explains the footprints. Three of hers. None of his.
It did rain... Brendan Harris couldn't be much more than one-fifty.
You honestly think that kid has it in him?
No.
Your pal, Dave, though. He's a slim guy.
How'd we get to him?
We're getting to him now.
Whitey, he's just a guy who was in the bar.
The last place she went, Sean, the last place. There's something wrong about that guy. (beat) Did you see his hand?
Yeah... You seriously want to take a look at Dave Boyle?
Just a little one.
Jimmy gets out of his car, walks around and pops the trunk. He pulls out a dress wrapped in plastic film. As he heads for the entrance...  63.
One of the "SONS" sits across the desk from Jimmy. The dress is draped over the chair beside him. The Son fills out a form with a gold pen. Jimmy looks far away.
I'd suggest two sets of visiting hours. From three to five and then seven to nine.
Yeah, that's fine.
Good. Have you thought about flowers?
I'll call Knopfler's this afternoon.
Good. And the notice?
The notice?
Yes. The obituary. We can take care of it if you'll just give us the basic information. Jimmy reaches out, straightens a fold in the dress.
If you'd prefer donations in lieu of flowers, things like that. I can --
(looks over) Where is she?
Who?
My daughter.
Um, downstairs. In the basement.
I'd like to see her.  64. The Son blinks back at Jimmy, looks a little unnerved.

lying on a stainless steel table, a sheet pulled up under her chin. Her hair clean and combed, her face dusted with makeup. Eyes closed, but no longer clenched tight. The Son stands in the doorway, shifting nervously as Jimmy steps up, stands over his daughter. Jimmy gets down on his haunches, his eyes even with Katie's face. He rests his chin on his forearm, looks at his daughter a long moment. Finally, softly, gently:
I'm going to kill him, Katie. I'm going to find him before the police do and I'm going to kill him.
Did you say something, Mr. Marcus? Jimmy answers without looking back.
The notice. It should read: ‘Katherine Marcus, beloved daughter of James and Marita, deceased, stepdaughter of Annabeth, and sister to Sara and Nadine. As the gold pen flies in the Son's hand...
Whitey and Sean get out of their car. At the same moment, Dave is exiting. He stops short, forces a smile.
You guys again? Whitey's smile isn't as forced.
We're like two bad pennies.
You dropping in on Jimmy?
Yeah.  65.
Did you have some kind of, what, break in the case?
Just paying our respects. Where you off to?
Annabeth got a craving for cigarettes. I'm going to get some. See you in a minute. As Dave moves past them, Whitey does his best Columbo.
What happened to your hand, by the way? Dave stops short, manages a twisted grin. ANGLE TO INCLUDE SECOND FLOOR WINDOW Celeste looking down on them, listening.
Huh? Oh, garbage disposal. It was jammed and I stuck my hand down there. Then it started up again. Stupid, huh?
Painful.
Dave nods, continues on his way. Whitey and Sean watch him.
Garbage disposal. Bullshit.
Yeah, well, it doesn't mean he killed anybody either. Come on. As they start up the stairs...
Her breath starts to come in heaves. She looks like a bird in a cage.  66.
As Annabeth answers the door to reveal Sean and Whitey. Sean holds out a cigarette, smiles.

Play it again.
A dive backed up against the river. A few old-timers, a few pool tables. Dave and Val sit in a booth. There are four empty shot glasses and a nearly empty pitcher of beer.

This one time back in the day, right? We take off this stamp collector. Rob him, tie him up and go. Me, my brother Nick and this kid Carson Leverett who couldn't tie his own fucking shoes if you didn't show him.  101. Dave laughs; this is really funny.

So we're coming down the elevator and we're wearing suits so we fit in. And this old lady gets on and starts freaking out. So I turn to Nick and he's looking at Carson because the fucking bonehead's still got his Ronald Reagan mask on.
And you guys didn't notice?
Little shit like that happened on jobs all the time. That's why Jimmy was so missed. He saw the whole field, man.
Why do you think be went straight?
One word pure and simple... Katie.
What about you?
I like the night too much. Day's just something you sleep through. Another shot?
I should slow down. Till we eat.

Come on, don't go pussy on me. Before Dave can answer, Val is on his way to the bar. A passing headlight flashes white in Dave's face. As he blinks, a silhouette comes through the door. As the door shuts and Dave's vision clears, he realizes it's Jimmy. Jimmy nods at Dave and then goes to Val at the bar. Says something in his ear. Val looks back at Dave and nods. The two of them head over carrying three shots and a bottle. Jimmy sits in across from Dave while Val slides next to him.
How's it going?  102.
I'm a little drunk. You gain some weight? You look bigger. Jimmy smiles, passes out the shots.
To our children. They down the shots. Jimmy immediately pours another round.
I always liked this bar.
Yeah. No one bothers you.
That's important. No one bothering you in this life. No one fucking with you or your loved ones. Right, Dave?
Absolutely. It's the funniest thing Val ever heard.
This guy's a hoot. He can get you going. Jimmy smiles at Dave, but it's pure frost.
Yeah?
Oh yeah. My man, Dave.

Seething purpose, Brendan enters, pulls a kitchen chair over to the butler's pantry. Standing on the chair, he looks up a beat at the slatted ceiling. He reaches up and presses with his right palm. A section of slats lifts up and away revealing an opening in the ceiling. Brendan looks up a beat, reaches into the black.  103.
Brendan's hand looks like it's playing an imaginary keyboard as it bounces and gropes in the dust and wood chips for something that is not there. His father's gun.
As he realizes he's not going to find it.

No... He returns the slat to its place, steps off the chair. He brings the chair back to the kitchen table and site down on it. Sits down so he's facing the door in the center of the apartment. And as Brendan waits..
Dave's having trouble focusing. Jimmy and Val seem like they've forgotten he's here.
Remember we took Ray Harris here that one time?
Sure. Good old Ray.
He was a hoot, too. Most people called him 'Just Ray,' but I called him Ray Jingles. As Dave tries to concentrate, Val leans into him.

This guy, right? He carried like ten bucks in change in his pocket, in case he had to make a phone call to Libya or some fucking place. Val laughs, lights a cigarette. As the smoke climbs up into Dave's face, he looks across at Jimmy who watches him with a flat, determined expression. As Jimmy smiles, Dave swallows, takes a deep suck of air.
You all right?  104. Dave holds up a hand as it surges up inside him.
Oh shit...
Dave?
I'm going to be sick. A flicker of a look between Val and Jimmy. Val slides out.
Use the back door. Huey don't like cleaning it off toilet rims. Val grips Dave's shoulders, turns him and heads him off for a door at the far end of the bar.
As Dave pushes through...
Bursting open. But, we're in...
And Silent Ray is arriving home with John O'Shea in tow. Brendan watches from the kitchen.
Hey, Ray. Come in here a second. Ray comes in. John stops in the doorway holding a duffel bag. Brendan pulls a second chair out with his foot.
Sit down, Ray. Ray catches a vibe, looks a little suspicious, but he sits.
Who do you hate?  105. Ray stares back at him.
Come on, who? Ray "signs" an answer.
No one? Who do you love? Ray looks down at his shoes, then up at Brendan. Finally, he points a finger at his brother.
You love me? (as Ray nods) What about Ma? Ray looks down again, shakes his head. "No."
Okay. You love me so much, I want to hear you say it. Ray looks back up, confused.
I know you can speak. So say you love me. Ray looks back over his shoulder at John.
Don't look at him, look at me. Now say it, say you love me.

Out back. One light over the door. And we're TRACKING BACK WITH Dave as he stumbles through the weeds. Drops to his hands and knees at the edge of the Mystic River. We're BACK BEHIND as he heaves, empties his stomach into the dirty water. Finally, he lurches to his feet, wipes his mouth with the back of his hand. He takes a few deep breaths, feels better. And when Dave finally turns around, Jimmy and Val are standing there. One on either side of the door, the light bulb burning between them. Dave grins.  106.
Hey, guys. Come to make sure I didn't fall in?
Ray sitting across from Brendan, freaking out a little at his brother's request.

Come on, say you love me. Finally Ray stands, holding his middle finger in Brendan's face and then turns to go. Brendan is on him in a flash. He grabs Ray by the hair and jerks him back. Ray flies over the kitchen table, slams into the wall and hits the floor.

You love me so much you kill my fucking girl friend?! Huh? That gets John O'Shea moving. Motoring for the door. But Brendan's all over him. Grabbing him by the scruff of the neck, he bounces him off the door, spins him around.
My brother never does anything without you, O'Shea! Never! Brendan punches him twice in the face, breaking his nose. John hits the floor, curls into a ball spitting blood.

I'm coming back. He kicks John, heads back for Ray who's just standing. Brendan slaps him so hard he reels into the sink. Brendan grabs him by the shirt. Tears and blood stream down Ray's face. Brendan throws him to the floor. Spreading Ray's arms, Brendan kneels on him.
Speak, you fucking freak or I swear I'll kill you! Speak!  107.
As Sean and Whitey enter. They freeze at:
Say her name! Katie! Say it or you die! As they start hard up the steps.

Ray shakes his head as Brendan looms. There's a LOUD COUGH behind them. Brendan looks over his shoulder to see John O'Shea on his feet, Ray Senior's gun in his hand. Aimed. But as the front door bursts open, John wheels, finds himself pointing the .38 point blank at Sean. Sean's hand is on his Glock, but it's still holstered. He stops short; Whitey filling the door behind him. As Sean blinks down the barrel... Whitey's eyes flicker past to Brendan and Ray.
Kid, you need to point that gun at the floor. Okay?
(re: Sean's gun) That's a Glock, right? Sean nods as time stands still and his life flashes.
(big smile) You wanna draw on me? Come on.
No. I don't want to hurt a kid. And it looks like someone else beat me to it. John remembers. Looks quite deadly.
Brendan fucking punched me. Broke my nose.
We'll arrest him for it if you want. Haul his ass to jail.  108.

I don't want him arrested. I want him fucking dead. As the .38 sweeps away back toward Brendan, Sean reaches out, claps a hand over John's wrist. BOOM! The GUN DISCHARGES into the wall as Sean strips it away, knocking John to the floor.

Motherfucker. Whitey kneels to cuff John who's now crying like a baby. Sean walks forward toward Brendan. Brendan slides off his brother, just sits on the floor looking up at Sean. Sean shrugs, almost apologetically.
We know.
What? What do you know? Sean looks back at John, down at Ray, then back to Brendan. Sean finally shakes his head.
Nothing.
Jimmy puts his arm around Dave's shoulder, leads him along the river. Val walks a few paces behind.

Let me tell you about Ray Harris. He was a buddy of mine. Used to visit me in prison. Used to check up on Marita and Katie and my mother and see if they needed anything. But he also put me in prison. He ratted me off.
Shit. That's terrible.
My wife had cancer.
I remember, man. I --  They stop. 109.

Ray Harris robbed me of being with her. I know we all die alone, but I could have helped her with the dying. Not the death, but the dying. You see what I'm saying? ‘Dave takes a half step away, faces Jimmy.
Why are you telling me this? Jimmy points. Far below the Tobin Bridge, at a rotted cluster of pilings, a small boat with an outboard motor tied up.
I made Ray kneel down right over there and I shot him twice. Once in the chest, once in the throat. We were both crying when I did it.
Hey, Jimmy, I don't --
Ray begged. Pregnant wife. Little Brendan. Said he knew me. Said I was a good man... How about you, Dave? Do you think I'm a good man?
What is it you think I did, Jimmy?
As I sunk Ray in the river, I could feel God watching me. Shaking his head. Not mad, just, I guess the way you'd get when a puppy shits on your rug.
You think I killed Katie, don't you?
Don't talk, Dave. Panic rising, Dave sees Val holds a gun in his hand.
No, no, no. I killed someone, but it wasn't Katie.
Is this the mugger story?  110.
He wasn't a mugger. He, he was a child molester. He was having sex with this kid in his car. He was a wolf; he was. a vampire.

The child prostitute we saw Dave try to talk to. Getting into a car with a man. The kid's head disappears below the dash. And then Dave is there. Dave hauls the man from the car, his pants down around his knees as Dave pounds his head on the pavement. The boy jumps out the passenger side, runs away.
Of course, Dave, sure. You killed a child molester.
Yeah, well, me and the boy.
Oh, the molested kid helped you?
No.
No what? You said you and a boy.
Young Dave running but sounding like an animal.
No, no, forget that. My head gets fucked up sometimes. I --

Your wife thinks you killed Katie. And you'd rather have her believe that than, what, you killed a child molester? Most people really don't mind when a child molester dies, Dave. Why didn't you just tell Celeste the truth?  111.
I, I don't know. Maybe I thought I was turning into him. I didn't kill Katie!
And I didn't hear of any dead guys being found lately.
I put him in the trunk of my car. Dumped his body in the woods --
Letting this bag of shit explain, Jim? You kidding me?
Shut up, Val... (to Dave) Katie was nineteen. You know? Nineteen and she never did nothing to you. Why'd you kill her?
The DRIVER slamming his hand on the roof.
Get in!
Look at me, Jimmy.
I'm looking, Dave. I'm looking.
LOOKING DOWN from a second floor window at young Jimmy who site on the curb below. As Dave's mom pulls the blind shut from behind him.
Why'd you do it?  112. FLASHBACK --— CELLAR Feet coming down. Young Dave burying his face in the rags. Young Dave pounding on the bulkhead.
Adult Dave pounding on the molester in the parking lot.
Me and my son, me and Celeste, there's so many things to make right.
Make them right now. Start now. Admit what you did.
No more lies, no more secrets, I want to go home to Celeste. I want to feel Celeste.
Yeah. Good. Right after you do your time. I did mine. Do yours. Admit what you did.
The boy...
One more time about the boy and I will open you up. Jimmy holds a wicked-looking buck knife. Dave dry heaves. Jimmy nearly does himself. Even Val looks confused as Jimmy blinks out toward the river.

I thought I was done. I thought I had left killing people and dumping them in the river behind. (turns to Dave) Admit what you did and you'll live. Say it out loud and you'll breathe. You'll go to jail, but I will give you your life. Finally, Dave decides it's a way to save his life, maybe even a way to ease Jimmy's grief.  113.
Yeah, yeah, I did it. Jimmy closes his eyes, lowers the knife. Val can't believe what he's watching.
Why...
That night in McGills, she reminded me of a dream I've had.
What dream?
A dream of youth. I don't remember having one. And she was the dream of it, and I just snapped. Jimmy opens his eyes again. He's trembling.
So it was the dream, then?
The dream, yeah. You'd know what I mean. If you'd got in that car instead of me.

(hardens ) But I didn't get in the car, Dave. You did. We're CLOSE ON them. And then Dave gets a funny look on his face. A funny face and then he looks down. Looks down in time to see Jimmy's hand pulling the knife back from his guts. Blood gushes down onto Dave's jeans.
Yes! That's what I'm talking about. Dave looks back at Jimmy, who turns, sends the knife sailing into the Mystic. Jimmy looks back over.

We bury our sins here, Dave. We wash them clean.  114. Dave suddenly drops, finds himself sitting in the tall weeds. Hands trying to hold his guts in. He looks up, watches as Val hands the gun to Jimmy.
He's moving his lips. See his fucking lips moving?
I got eyes, Val. Finally, Dave's words come out in a whisper.
I wasn't ready.
Like I said. You do this part alone. And Jimmy raises the GUN, places the barrel against Dave's forehead. And as Dave closes his eyes...

head_text.subj: THE MEMORY BULKHEAD BURSTS OPEN AND... A MUZZLE FLASH

text: And we PAN DOWN to find ourselves ON...

Where it all began. Jimmy sits on the curb, by the sidewalk where they once wrote their names. Jimmy, Sean and half of Dave. Jimmy sips his bourbon from a pint. A car pulls up across the street. Sean. He walks over.
Annabeth said you might be here. (re: bourbon) Tough night? Jimmy nods.
Me, too. Saw a bullet with my name on it.  115. Jimmy holds up the pint. Sean takes it, swallows a long pull. As he hands it back...
We got them.
Got who?
Katie's killers. Got them cold. It's trying to get in, but it hasn't sunk yet.
Killers? Plural?
Kids, actually. Ray Harris's son, Ray Junior, and a kid John O'Shea. They confessed a couple hours ago.
No question?
None.
Why?

They don't know. They were playing with a gun. Saw a car coming so one of them lies down in the middle of the street. Car swerves, clutch kicks out. Katie. O'Shea says they meant to just scare her, but the gun went off. She hit him with the door and ran. They chased her so she wouldn't tell no one.
And the beating they gave her?
Ray Junior had a hockey stick. Jimmy looks around. It's sinking now. Sean crouches down beside him.
Go easy, Jim. Take a breath. (beat) (MORE )
Look at me. I got a call from Celeste Boyle. She was hysterical. She said Dave's missing. Said you might know where he is. Jimmy looks at Sean, but can't find any words.
We need to talk to him. Boston police found the body of a guy this morning. In the woods behind McGill's.
A guy?
A pedophile with three priors. They want to talk to Dave about it. Jimmy lurches up past Sean. Trying to get a grip.
When was the last time you saw Dave, Jimmy? Finally, standing there in the middle of the street...
Last time I saw Dave? Dave Boyle?
Yeah, Dave Boyle.
It was twenty-five years ago. Going down this street in the back of that car.
Thanks for busting Katie's killers, Sean. Really. Maybe if you'd been a little faster though? It's so goddamn awful. They look at each other a sad beat.
You going to send Celeste five hundred a month, too? Eyes brimming, Jimmy looks back up the street. Sean does the same. Right where they were when Dave was driven away.  117.
Sometimes I think, I think all three of us got in that car. And all this, it's just a dream.
A dream, sure.
In reality we're still eleven-year-old boys trapped in a cellar. Imagining what our lives would have been if we'd escaped.

Maybe you're right. Who the fuck knows? Jimmy turns and starts walking down the street. Sean just watches after him. Watches as Jimmy walks down the same street, disappears the same way Dave did. Sean's CELL PHONE RINGS. Finally, he answers.
Hello? No answer. HIGHWAY sounds from the other end. Sean knows who it is, finally knows what to say...
I'm sorry... I need you to know that. I pushed you away. A long pause.
I'm sorry, too. It's been so messed up. Loving you, hating you.
Come home.
You change the locks or anything? Sean smiles with a sudden sense of surprise and relief.
Everything's just the way you left it.
Nora.  118.
What's that?
Nora. That's our daughter's name, Sean.
Nora... And Sean starts to walk toward his car, still talking on the phone, laughing. And as the SOUND FADES OFF, we HOLD ON the sidewalk, on the names written so long ago.
On the sidewalk. People lining up. And we TILT UP TO the Buckingham Day Parade. Floats, color guard, politicians in convertibles. Over it all...
I killed the wrong man. This is what I've done and I can't undo it.
Shhh, Jimmy. Shhh.
Annabeth steps up to Jimmy, starts to unbutton his shirt.
I want to hear your heart. She places an ear to his chest. Jimmy nearly can't breathe under his burden. We hear the PARADE OUTSIDE.
Last night, when I put the girls to bed, I told them how big your heart was.
Annabeth --
I told them how much you loved Katie. Because you created her and sometimes your love for her was so big, your heart felt like it was going to explode from loving her.  119.
Please stop.

I told them their daddy loved them that much, too. That he had four hearts and they were all filled up and aching with a love that meant we would never have to worry. Annabeth pulls off her own shirt, presses herself to him.
I told them their daddy would do whatever he had to for those he loved. And that is never wrong. That can never be wrong. No Matter what their daddy had to do.
You knew?
Celeste called looking for you. Told me about Dave. Told me what she told you. Said she was worried something might happen. She kisses his throat, starts to undo his belt.
Why didn't you call?
Because they're weak.
Who's weak?

Everyone. Everyone but us. We will never be weak. And you. You could rule this town. A beat as Jimmy stares at her. And then he kisses her. Hungry for this woman. His woman. Passion builds precipitously. As she returns it, between breaths:
And, Jim? After? Let's take the girls down to the parade. Katie would've liked that.  120. Jimmy lifts her up. She hooks her legs around him.

It streams along. Sean stands watching with his wife Lauren and his baby daughter. A float passes by filled with children who shout, laugh and wave. All except for one who's lost, sad, haunted. The child's eyes find Sean's for just an instant and then he's gone. Sean snaps from the sudden trance, looks across the street at Jimmy, Annabeth, their daughters and a few of the Savage brothers. Waving at the parade, happy and strong. Suddenly aware of being watched, Jimmy's head swivels. His eyes lock on Sean's. Jimmy gives Sean the smallest smile. And Sean points a "finger gun." Drops his thumb on the imaginary hammer. And as Jimmy's smile widens... FADE TO BLACK.
